Day-trip to deCordova Sculpture Park & Museum.
Saturday, August 21st
51 Sandy Road, Lincoln MA
*Meet in the museum parking lot at 10AM.

Museum Admission Fees: Adults – 12.00, seniors & college students & youths (6-18) – 8.00, children (0-5) free.

Museum doors open at 10AM

There might be a parking fee ... not sure.

Pets are permitted on the grounds, but not inside the museum.

This event was suggested by Allen, who will be taking his bike on the 8:35AM MBTA train (Fitchburg line) out of North Station, arriving in Lincoln around 9:15 AM. There is no fee for taking bikes on the train. It's about a 10-minute ride from the Lincoln train stop to the museum, where we can hang out until the auto-folks catch up with us.

This would likely entail a good part of the day because there is so much to see.

deCordova encompasses 35 acres of beautiful rolling woodlands and lawns in Lincoln and is the largest park of its kind in New England. A former private estate, the outdoor sculpture park is open to the public every day of the year from dawn 'til dusk, and contains approximately 75 artworks at any given time. Many of them are hidden like lost treasures or archeological wonders among the trees – some so clever as to seemingly blend in with their surroundings, and they come and go such that there is almost always something new to be discovered. It can take a whole afternoon just to wander the grounds, and the museum itself features some of the best in contemporary artists.

Driving directions are available on the website at:
http://Day-trip... to deCordova Sculpture Park & Museum.

*Also, please note that the museum does have a small café inside with sandwiches and drinks, but the prices are somewhat high and selections are limited. People might want to bring their own snacks and water along with them.

*There is also a great gift store on the property located in a separate building so you don’t have to buy an admission ticket just to peruse the wares and baubles of many local artisans.

CURRENT EXHIBIT:
The current main exhibit within the museum features the work of Chakaria Booker, one of America's most important contemporary African-American sculptors. Chakaia Booker: The exhibition includes monumental outdoor sculptures, indoor sculpture in a wide variety of formats and sizes, drawings, and photographs. Chakaia Booker is best known for her work in recycled materials featuring cut-up automobile tires that are reassembled on wooden or steel armatures to create abstract sculptures. Thes sculptures, and the surface patterns that they create, reference African textiles and body decoration to evoke issues of black culture, identity, gender, and environmentalism.

This show closes at the end of the month.

To see examples of her work visit the museums link:
http://www.decordova....
